ville—I know George Fossitt as a lodger of Workman's, and Patterson as Workman's brother-in-law—I have had conversations with Fossitt about a burglary in Westminster Bridge Road, but he did not mention Maudsley's—at the end of January, 1878, he showed me a blank key, and told me that he and Workman had a good job on—I have heard Fossitt and Work man talking the matter over together—they said the key was made at Workman's house and took two days to make, and it fitted the safe it was intended to open—Fossitt told me that there was about 2,000l. in the safe—I told him I should not let that die a natural death, and he said, "I should think not; it's something worth attending to"—I called on him frequently at Workman's house, and Mrs. Workman generally opened the door, and was present at several conversations—on Whit Sunday Workman and his wife and Patterson were in the parlour—as Patterson left to go home to dinner he said to the Workmans, "Now, remember your promise; for if you miss this chance of seeing it you won't get another '—I went again on the Wednesday, and I talked about being caught in the rain on Whit-Monday, and Workman said they were in the same predicament coming from Westminster Bridge—I said, "Well, did you see what you went to see?" he said—"We saw it all"—I said, "You know where to go and put your hand on it now?" and he said, "Yes, I can find it blindfolded"—after that he got a situation for the purpose of doing it, and I went round to his house on a Tuesday morning when he had been there a little over a week, and Mrs. Workman said he had been in on the Sunday and wanted to see me very particularly—she said, "There's something up there for you," pointing to a picture on the wall, and I found two pieces of wax at the top of the frame—she said, "You are to make them, and I am to take them down to-morrow"—I said, "I can't make keys from these; they

arc damaged; you had better take the wax down again to-morrow, and let him take them afresh"—she went down on Wednesday, and I called on Thursday, and again on Friday morning—Workman lost his situation at Aldershot after being there 9 or 10 days—I made another key for another safe job we had on—Mrs. Workman showed it to Patterson in my presence—she said she liked to handle those sort of things, and Patterson said it was like a key that fitted theirs, but neater made—Workman told me Fossitt had got three months—I said, "He won't be in time to do the affair you have on," Maudsley's—He said, "We'll put Baker into it"—I said, "You don't mean to push Old George out of it altogether?"—he said, "No; we have arranged to allow him so much out of each of our corners; I dare say it will be about a cent."—that is 100l.—six of us proposed to go to Staines on Easter Monday, but only Fossitt and Workman went, and Fossitt fell, and Workman got away—"fell" means he was caught.

Cross-examined by Arthur Workman. Only Mrs. Workman was present when she showed me the impressions of the cash box keys you left to be given to me to make, and she only was present when you told me you had been to the place and could find it blindfolded—the police came to see me at Pentonville, and said they had heard I knew something about the intended burglary, and asked me if I would give evidence in this case; I asked if I should get any benefit, and they said they could not promise anything or hold out any inducement.

WILLIAM BROWN . I am a labourer, at 1, Garden Row, London Road—in May last I was sent to Wandsworth Gaol for a month—Workman was in the next cell, and spoke to me on many occasions while going to chapel or out in the exercise ground—he asked me to take a message to a Mrs. Clark, 104, Warner Road, when I got out, and to tell her the "Coppers," Hunt and Chamberlain, had been, and he was sorry "Pat" had "fell;" they wanted him (Workman) to come up and give evidence against Pat, but he told them he knew nothing about it, and they went away very cross—Workman asked me to go his wife, 14, Bath Place, Addington Square, Camherwell, and tell her the Coppers had been about Maudsley's job, and she must keep her "guts" what she knew about it, and that he had told the Coppers he had been with her to Maudsley's 18 months ago to look at the models while the clerks were in the country.

Cross-examined by Arthur Workman. I have been convicted of felony once before—your wife was not at Bath Place, and I went to her at Cam
berwell Workhouse as you told me, but did not give her the message; she said, "Come down to-night"—I gave Mrs. Clark the message—I went to Carter Street and gave information that you had given me a message to your wife that she was not to give information to the police if they came that you had been to Maudsley's to see the keys—a man stopped me and said I should be well paid if I did not give information against you—the police summoned me to come here—I do not know if I shall be paid as a witness—I was fetched to the police-court.
Cross-examined by Emma Workman. I told you at Camberwell I had a message from your husband, and he was very sorry Pat had fell—I did not go down at night.

Re-examined. The man I met in the street had a black moustache, and was with Mrs. Workman—he touched me on the shoulder and said, "You have just come out of 'stir,' haven't you?"—I said "Yes"—and he said,
"What did he say to you?"—I took him up the next street and told him, and he said, "If you don't go and give information you will get well paid for it"—this was about 5.30 or 5.45.

DANIEL HUNT (Detective-Inspecter P.). I and Chamberlain had Work
man in custody last September—I know his wife and Rogers, alias Dowthwaite—Workman made certain communications to me before his conviction, and subsequently his wife also made certain communications to me—I was at Slough on 26th March, when Davis and Harding were tried and convicted—Harding, alias Biker, made a statement to me before his conviction, and at three interviews after his conviction, in consequence of which I saw Mrs. Chandler—I obtained an order from the Home Secretary and saw William Chandler, and made certain inquiries, and then reported to Scotland Yard, and this prosecution was instituted—I obtained an order to see Workman, and saw him at Wandsworth on 24th May, and told him the object of my visit, and that Patterson was in custody with others on this charge, and said, "Now do you know anything about the case?"—he said, "No; I can have nothing to say in the case"—I said, "Do you know Patterson?"—he said, "Yes; I have known him about 16 years"—I said, "We are in possession of the whole facts of the case. We know that you can give evidence in this case if you like. Will you do it?"—he said, "No; I can have nothing to do with that job; I can't give evidence against my brother-in-law. Besides that, it was nearly two years ago it was talked about?—I said, "Do you recollect being in a certain public-house when the keys were shown to Baker by Patterson in your presence?"—he said, "Yes, I recollect being in a public-house with Patterson and Baker at the Father Red Cap, Camber well Green, one Sunday evening last May (1876), but Patterson did not show Baker the keys. In fact, I do net think Baker ever saw them. I went with my wife once about fifteen months ago, and had a look ever the place referring to Maudsley's. Patterson showed us over the premises and showed us the models"—he declined to give further testimony—on 23rd May with Inspector Chamberlain I saw Mrs. Workman at the Orange Tree Beerhouse, Avill Street, camberwell—I said, "Patterson is in custody charged with others conspiring to commit a burglary at Messrs. Maudsley's and it is said you have been there and know all about it; will you tell us what you know I"—she said, "No. I shall have nothing at all to do with it. I know nothing about it; I have heard it was intended to break in; but that was sometime ago"—I said, "Well, if you decline to give the necessary infor
mation there are plenty others who can," mentioning Chandler and his wile—she said, "Mrs. Chandler, let her say what she likes. She is only wild she didn't have the job to climb blooming well herself"—I asked her if I should see her again in the evening, and she said "Yes, come alone. See me at 7 o'clock at my house"—I called there about 6.30, and she was not at home—I saw her about 7 with Mrs. Patterson, the prisoner's wife, leaving the house, and after she had left Mrs. Patterson I spoke to her again about giving me information and told her I was going to see her husband—she said, "I'll wait and see what Arthur does"—she said she could not give in
formation as she had not been paid for the last job—she had given evidence in Harding's case—she said, if her husband gave evidence she would do the same—she afterwards said, "As Patterson has found me and ray children food and shelter for two months after Arthur was put away, I cannot find it in my

heart to hurt him. I know the affair was arranged and would have come off had it been kept quiet. I think it is nearly two years ago it was first talked about. I went with my husband once into Mr. Maudsley's place. We went to see the models. Patterson showed us over the premises. We had some ale there—I know some keys were made, two lots, and I believe that Baker had them with him when he was taken at Slough As the job did not come off you can do nothing with it. You can do nothing with Patterson—Patterson and Baker did come to my house several times—I intended to wait until the job was done, and if a reward was offered, to give informa
tion—lid you expect to find the keys when you reached Patterson's house?" I said "Yes, I suppose they did. I was not there myself." She said, "Ah! clever men never keep those things in their own houses"—I said, well! if the affair had taken place she would not have got so much as she thought, perhaps. She said, "If it had been done at the right time, there would have been a good lot there, and they did not mean to do it except when there was plenty there. Sometimes it's more than at others. I will think the matter over, and perhaps I'll tell you more about it. I'll wait and see what Arthur does."
Cross-examined by Arthur Workman. This conversation was on the evening of the 23rd May, the day preceding that on which I saw you at Wandsworth.

Cross-examined by Emma Workman. I did not ask you to go to Mr. Wontner—as a fact he would not be engaged in the case then—when I saw you at the Orange Tree I asked you if you had reconsidered your determination, and whether you would become a witness, and you declined—I was then unaware what steps would be taken—you asked me if the keys were in the bag found on Baker at Slough—I said, "No, there were no keys of that description"—I said, "There is a sovereign in my pocket for you"—that had no reference to this case—you said, "Those keys, if we could find them, would be worth a thousand pounds," and asked me how much I would give for them—I did not say, "I will give you 3l. for them."

WILLIAM CHAMBERLAIN (Inspector L). I have been present and have heard Hunt's statements as to these conversations, and they are sub
stantially correct—I took Patterson in custody on the 22nd May, in Kennington Road—I said, "I am a police officer, and hold a warrant for your apprehension for being concerned with others in conspiring to break into your master's premises, Maudsley's"—he said, "I know nothing about it; who are the others?"—I said, "A man named Davis or Jones, and another named Harding, who were taken in custody at Slough some weeks ago for robbery"—Mrs. Workman made a statement to me after she was in custody—she said, "Mr. Chamberlain, this is a very bad job"—I said, "Yes, it is"—she said, "I wish I had told you and Mr. Hunt the truth the other night when I saw you at the Orange Tree"—I said, "Why didn't you?"—she said, "I hardly knew what to say about it then, I have been in the place (meaning Maudsley's) with my husband. Patterson took him and me in. They didn't allow me to go over the place with them. They shut me in a room whilst they went and done what they wanted"—I said, "Why did they do that?"—she said, "Patterson was afraid that the persons in the next house might see a woman in the house, which would cause some suspicion."
JOHN TRIMME . I am manager to Messrs. Maudsley—I have been in

Court and heard Harding's description of the premises and it is perfectly correct—we were in the habit of paying the men on Saturday—the money was obtained from the Bank on Friday morning, and kept in safes in the room as described by Harding, in iron safes in a wooden locker—the wages are sometimes as high as 2,500l. a week.

Cross-examined by Patterson. The amount last Friday was consider
ably over 1,000l.—it ranged from 800l. to 2,000l., according to the number of men—we have had nearly 2,000 men during the last 12 months.
WALTER HENRY MAUDSLEY . I am a member of the firm of Maudsley and Co., Engineers—I have heard our premises described to-day and that description is accurate.

Cross-examined by Patterson. You have been in our employ about four and a half years—I believe we received a good character with you, but Mr. Trimme can speak to that—you have been during the last three years in the office and I have seen you almost daily and have never seen anything in your conduct to lead me to suspect you were connected with such men as the other prisoners—you used to fetch the money on Fridays, you and another messenger together, in bags from the Bank—I cannot say if you had an opportunity of seeing the cheque drawn every Friday—there are two cheques drawn, the larger amount on Friday and the other on Saturday morning—it has not been so low as 400l.—I cannot speak as to the number of men we had.
Re-eximined. I did not know when we took Patterson into our service that he had been sentenced to penal servitude—I have since ascertained it.
By the Prisoner. I believe that was 15 years ago—I have seen the papers.

WILLIAM CHAMBERLAIN (Re-examined). I had a conversation with Patterson when he was taken with Workman—he said, "It was through him partly that I got into trouble before—it is some years ago now since I had the five years"—he volunteered the statement—I had these papers with me and showed him his photograph (produced) and he said, "Yes, it's quite right" (certificate produced)—he had a ticket of leave and failed to report himself, and ought to have been apprehended.

Cross-examined by Patterson. You freely acknowledged this, and told me the date, and where you had been—you gave me three written characters from where you had been employed—you had been at one place nine months; at another place they could not find you in their books, and at Smith and Taylor's, Pimlico, they admitted that you were employed there as a labourer, but did not know how long.

p.hi: Patterson produced a written defence, denying the charge, and assenting that the witnesses' statements were wicked fabrications.

Arthur Workman, in his defence, stated that the police had not told the truth, and had been working the case up solely on the letter they had received from Harding, and that Harding's statement at the Police Court was a tissue of falsehoods, and that there was no evidence to support that of the convicts. He also stated that during the last thirty years he had been occupied as a grocer, a photographer, and as a police-constable, and was never a housebreaker, except once with Rogers, when in great poverty. Emma Workman, in her defence, stated that she knew nothing of the charge; that she never saw the keys, that she had been annoyed by the police every time her husband got into trouble, and that the evidence was perfectly false.

div1.p:
PATTERSON* and ARTHUR WORKMAN**†—
GUILTY .—
Two Years' Imprisonment.

EMMA WORKMAN.—
GUILTY .—
Twelve Months'Imprisonment.

JONES.—
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO TUESDAY, AUGUST 5TH, 1879.
